im.selector features a very small (~ 200 lines of actual code) CSS selector engine that can do most common CSS selection tasks; a very small subset of what full blown CSS selector engines support. For comfort: the performance of the IM selector engine is up to par with jQuery's Sizzle library (one of the fastest on the market).

CSS selector support

im.selector supports the following type of selectors, and any combination of them:

  • node name: 'span'
  • class name: '.button'
  • node and class name: 'span.button'
  • descendants: 'div p span'
  • child nodes: 'div > p > span'
  • multiple selectors: 'div, span'
  • id: '#singleton'
var allDiv = im('div'); // all divs in the document var buttons = im('a.button'); // all anchors with class button var widgets = im('p > .widget-a, p > .widget-b'); // widget-a and widget-b inside paragraphs var widgetSpansAndStrongs = widgets.find('span, strong'); // spans and strongs inside the widgets

Caching

im.selectNodes supports a CSS selector caching mechanism. The caching using two keys: the concatenated UUID of all context elements, and the selector. Caching can be controlled by adding a prefix to your css selectors:

  • '% .class' - auto mode
    Return cached result, or create new cached result and return that.
  • '%! .class' - set mode
    Create/overwrite new cached result, and return the new result.
  • '%? .class' - get mode
    Return cached result, returns empty array when not found.
im('% div.tooltip').each(function(){}); // will walk the dom to find im('% div.tooltip').each(function(){}); // will use cached result im('%! div.tooltip').each(function(){}); // will walk the dom and update the cache
